details.title: The calculating formulae, and experimental methods in error propagation analysis
details.standardTitle: The calculating formulae, and experimental methods in error propagation analysis

p: Jianfang Zhang received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Hangzhou University, Hangzhou, China, and the M.S. degree in statistics from the Institute of System Science and Mathematics, Chinese Academia of Science (CAS), Beijing, China, in 1982 and 1986, respectively.

Since 1986, he has been with the Department of Mathematics, Graduate University of CAS, where he is currently a Professor. His research interests are in applied statistics, experimental design and optimization, quality improving, and error propagation analysis.

authors.affiliation: Graduate Univ. of Chinese Acad. of Sci., Beijing, China
authors.name: Jianfang Zhang

details.abstract: Error propagation is a basic problem in analysing uncertainty of reliable systems. The model of error propagation can be expressed as y=f(X+Z), where f is a system or propagation function, X is an input vector of the system, Z is an error vector of X, and y is a response or an output of the system. The error propagation analysis is conducted mainly to calculate or estimate the mean and variance of y given Z distributed s-normally with zero means. In this paper, we first assume that f(X) is calculable, and can be expressed in Taylor-series expansion; and we introduce the exact formulae and some approximate formulae for calculating the mean and variance of y given Z being s-independent or s-dependent. Second, we discuss the moment-methods of estimation for the mean and variance of y by experimental design. These methods can also be used when y=f(X) is a calculable function that may not be differentiable. Third, we give an example for comparing the different methods of error propagation, and discuss some results and comments according to many examples examined. Fourth, we discuss the robustness and usability on the methods of error propagation analysis. Finally, we give several conclusions.

citations.title: The calculating formulae, and experimental methods in error propagation analysis

context.text: Kuo & Uppuluri [1] did a good review that included a framework or a standard analysis procedure to error propagation analysis in reliable systems.

references.title: A review of error propagation analysis in systems
references.text: W. Kuo, V. R. R. Uppuluri, "A review of error propagation analysis in systems", Microelectronics and Reliability, vol. 23, no. 2, pp. 235-248, 1983.

context.text: Helton & Davis [2] summarized some techniques for error propagation (or uncertainty and sensitivity) analysis including Monte Carlo analysis, differential analysis, response surface methodology, Fourier amplitude sensitivity test, Sobol's variance decomposition, fast probability integration, and Latin hypercube sampling.

Experimental methods for estimating error propagation are summarized by Helton & Davis [2], and include Monte Carlo analysis, the response surface methodology, Latin hypercube sampling; but also include the uniform design [18], and the partial derivatives estimation method [19].

references.title:
Latin hypercube sampling and the propagation of uncertainty
in analyses of complex systems
references.text: J. C. Helton, F. J. Davis, "Latin hypercube sampling and the propagation of uncertainty in analyses of complex systems", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 81, no. 1, pp. 23-69, July 2003.

references.title: Outer array and its cases
references.text: J. F. Zhang, "Outer array and its cases", Applied Statistics and Management (Chinese Magazine), vol. 15, no. 3, pp. 41-52, 1995.

context.text: These methods were first developed by the Japanese statistician Taguchi [12], [13], followed by John & Nicholas [14], and Zhang [8]–[11].
The original method for estimating \$E(y)\$ and \$Var(y)\$ was established by Taguchi [12].

In addition to Taguchi's suggestion [12], [13], and the idea of John & Nicholas [14], the theory of moment-design is mainly inspired by the fact that the calculating error or precision of formulae of error propagation is related to the number of maximum order of moments of \$Z\$ included.
3-order symmetric moment-design (with 2 runs) [12] .

context.text: These methods were first developed by the Japanese statistician Taguchi [12], [13], followed by John & Nicholas [14], and Zhang [8]–[11].
John & Nicholas [14] modified Taguchi's method, proposed the idea of moment-design, and established the method of product Gaussian quadrature.

In addition to Taguchi's suggestion [12], [13], and the idea of John & Nicholas [14], the theory of moment-design is mainly inspired by the fact that the calculating error or precision of formulae of error propagation is related to the number of maximum order of moments of \$Z\$ included.
5-order symmetric moment-design (with 3 runs) [14] .
7-order symmetric moment-design (with 4 runs) [14] .
